 Dreamweaver,
 The spark for this thread came from a post I saw on the "Homosexual Christians" thread stating that homosexuals could not truly be Christians. I agree with some of what all of you are saying. I agree that one can be saved by accepting God or confessing their faith and repenting (Catholics call this a baptism of desire). I believe this because although I believe that God has bound the sacraments, He is not bound by the sacraments-that is, it is a Scripturally and Traditionally clear fact that Jesus instituted the sacraments as necessary and appropriate but God is not limited by them in granting his salvation. I wanted to pose some ideas on other avenues into the entitlement of Christianity besides a confession of faith. And I think we all agree that one's faith must be lived-to live The Way most fully and most closely with Jesus then the sacraments are needed. 
 
 Concerning baptism, it was the Christian equivalent of Jewish circumcision. Circumcision occurred on the 8th day and the child was accepted into the Jewish faith. It was recognized that parents can and often do speak for their children when their children are unable to do so. At some point the child must accept or reject the faith of their family. But until they are able to make that decision they are entitled to the benefits of the faith as passed on by their family. If Jesus gave his grace and salvation as a gift then there is no reason why he wouldn't give that gift to children. Early Christians understood this:

 http://www.catholic.com/library/Early_Teachings_of_Infant_Baptism.asp 
 
 Baptism does have the power to save by the gift of grace:
